paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does the Earth-sized rocky exoplanet TRAPPIST-1 b retain a significant atmosphere despite its close, tidally locked orbit and strong stellar irradiation, and what are its properties?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Observed System
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: Phase-resolved thermal spectra from JWST MIRI
datasets_or_cohorts.description: The primary dataset consisting of JWST MIRI low-resolution, phase-resolved thermal spectra for the rocky exoplanet TRAPPIST-1 b.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Null/Bare-rock Scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: A computational model of the planet assuming an atmosphere-free, bare-rock surface with minimal heat redistribution (epsilon = 0).

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich Atmosphere Model
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An atmospheric retrieval model family featuring a moderate-pressure, CO2-rich composition to test for greenhouse gas absorption effects.

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets. (L47)
Retrieval assumptions (circulation, opacity priors, cloud treatment) affect the quantitative posteriors derived for atmospheric properties. (L48)
Degeneracies between composition, clouds/hazes, and circulation assumptions remain significant, limiting definitive constraint on one single atmospheric model. (L37)
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current JWST MIRI dataset. (L50)
